description:
For this memory game you need a brain the size of an elephant’s to keep up with the animals who often move between hiding places... Be careful not to lose  track of them...

Dans ce jeu de mémo, il faut une mémoire d’éléphant pour se souvenir de l’emplacement des animaux qui changent souvent de cachette… Attention à ne pas perdre le fil…

—description from the publisher

The first player to reproduce a castle with his cones wins!But you  have to be very observant because they all look alike

Un duel de constructeur : le premier qui reproduit la pyramide de la carte remporte la partie ! Mais attentions aux pièges et aux ressemblances !

—description from the publisher

Potlatch, the game, is a strategic, educational card game based on indigenous philosophies. It is designed to meet Washington's K-12 educational standards for teaching about native history, economics, culture, and government. The game was developed as a community effort with local elders and language experts. The game is written in both English and Lushootseed, the indigenous language of the Salish Pacific Northwest. Game mechanics are based on sharing resources to meet other players’ needs for food, materials, technology, and knowledge.

This is a collaborative game where there is not one winner. Success is determined by whether or not all houses have their resource needs met by the end of the game.

The game is named for the Potlatch, which is a ceremonial distribution and re-distribution of resources, property, food, knowledge, and wealth with the purpose of affirming social status via the historic economic systems of subsistence, prestige, and sharing. Potlatching is practiced by indigenous peoples of the Pacific NW coast of the U.S. and Canada. Historically it supported a large socio-economic system to maintain a high level of food production and to equalize food accessibility. Individuals, families, or communities host potlatches and planning takes a year or more. Skagit elder and historian, Vi Hilbert, wrote “Public acts of distributing valuables to guests were the ultimate confirmation of a host’s achievements and personal high-status in their family and community.”

Battle Quest is an adventure game for 1-4 people. Each player takes the roll of a heroic adventurer, seeking to make his or her fortune in the dark and dangerous areas of the world. It is a world of dragons and ogres, knights and wizards, swords and sorcery, where the life of your adventurer can be snuffed out at any moment.

Players start by choosing one of 4 characters - warrior, mage, thief, and treasure hunter. They then spend gold to buy a weapons, armor, equipment, and spells. Once that is done, the players set of for the dungeon. Players are exploring a hidden dungeon. Within the dungeon an ancient dragon lives. Players roll 2d6 to determine what they encounter on their turn - could be a creature, trap, pit, getting lost, or a locked door. Players can head back to town to buy more equipment. Encounters are resolved with 1 or a series of d6 die rolls. If they survive the encounter, players roll on a treasure table to determine what they have gained.

When they are ready, players can choose to encounter the dragon. First player to kill the dragon wins.

—description from the publisher

Get a Grip is a dexterity party game. Two players have to fulfil a task, givenby a revealed task with their thumb tied to the palm. Rules suggest, that adults should be handicapped vs. children by having additional two fingers bound with the provided cloth ribbon, while kids may use all four fingers, but never the thumb.

Tasks might be drawing a sketch or forming something out of Plasticine, but there are several others, e.g. twisting a coin like a gyroscope. Most tasks come with a time limit, after which the remaining would vote, who did the better job. (Because of that, the official minimum player number is four, although the challenge is always only taken by two players.) The winner of a round will take the card. In case of a tie, a new card is revealed and both cards are the stake for the next challenge. To win the game, three cards are required.

Contains Wheat.

Marbowling is a completely new twist on an old sport. In this game, a Shooter must navigate a Pro Ball marble down the 32" Lane, between the gutters and through the stationary pins to the scoring area.
    Step 1: Roll the 6 dice to determine the placement of pins (ex. 1-1-2-4-4-5 = a 1 pin, 2 pin, 4 pin, and 5 pin)
    Step 2: Place the pins in the pin holes according to the outcome of the dice roll.
    Step 3: Shoot - aim the Shooter Ramp and send your Pro Ball down the Lane (Trick Shots and Hook Shots are encouraged)
    Step 4: Score - The scoring area consist of 10, 20, 30, and 50 point pockets. A Shooter is allowed two attempts per frame or turn (1st ball = full points / 2nd ball = 1/2 points.) The highest score after 10 frames is the winner!

Messina 1347 takes place during the introduction of the plague epidemic (a.k.a. the "black death") and the spreading of its infection through town. During this time period, merchant ships delivering luxury goods to Europe brought to these countries an unprecedented epidemic — and one of the first affected cities was Messina, Italy.

In the game, players take the role of important Messina families who are leaving town and moving to the countryside out of fear of being infected by the plague. While doing this, they are focusing on saving other inhabitants and helping to fight the plague infection in town. They must also endeavor to prosper in their countryside residence, where they are temporarily accommodating rescued residents. They are all waiting there for the epidemic to subside, then they return to Messina to take over and dominate particular districts in the town.

Think fast before you pass! Dig into the fast-passing card game of Sporks. Choose which food to collect and race to get as many as you can, but stay sharp as you also need the right spork to win. The wild spork gives you the edge, but will you be quick enough to grab it?

—description from the publisher

In Tolomeo, players demonstrate their knowledge of astronomy to observe the sky and anticipate the planets' movement. Be careful because the speed of each planet differs in line with the Ptolemaic model, and you should consider the sun and moon as well. If you want a shot at victory, you have to spot astral conjunctions, make the best use of the comet, and take advantage of the planets' influence on each other.

—description from the publisher

The Snails on the Wall game is a simple roll and move game where players move their piece along the playing board wall according to the roll of a die. The first to reach the top is declared the winner

Europe is full of things to see and do, and you've decided to get a slice of the action in The Great Tour: European Cities. Transport tourists in your bus between the great cities to see the sights, from the La Scala in Milan to the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, and many others! However, you'll have to contend with your competitors who are less than eager to let you win.

In more detail, plan your journey, draw ticket cards, and drive your bus from one destination to the next. For each complete journey, you receive points that count toward your final score. You are also rewarded for each new destination, the most completed journeys, and more.

Keep your wheels turning because the great tour has just begun!

—description from the back of the box

The herd of horses is spread out across the whole paddock. But when they are collected for riding, all the horses come to the gate at top speed.

An exciting game to support quickness and hand-eye coordination.

Every player gets a set of identical cards, which look like Domino stones and show one or two horses in different colors.

The paddock cards form a draw pile. Once a paddock card is flipped, all players try to arrange their cards in the form of the shown paddock card as quickly as possible.

The quickest player wins the paddock card. When the draw pile with the paddock cards runs out, the player with the most paddock cards is the winner of the game.
—user summary (English)

Die Pferdeherde hat sich über die ganze Koppel verteilt. Doch wenn sie zum Reiten abgeholt werden, kommen alle Pferde ganz schnell ans Gatter.

Ein spannendes Ablegespiel, bei dem neben Schnelligkeit auch die Augen-Hand-Koordination gefördert wird.

Jeder Spieler erhält einen identischen Satz an Pferdekarten, die wie Dominosteine aufgebaut sind und 1 oder 2 Pferde in unterschiedlichen Farben aufweisen.

Vom Stapel mit den Koppelkarten wird eine Karte aufgedeckt und alle Spieler versuchen gleichzeitig, die Koppel so schnell wie möglich nachzubauen.

Der jeweils schnellste Spieler bekommt die Koppelkarte als Belohnung. Wer am Ende die meisten Koppelkarten gewonnen hat, gewinnt auch das Spiel.
—user summary (German)

In Buzz Around the players control a swarm of insects and try to get through a field of flowers, surviving the hazards that threaten them! In addition to the basic roll and move system the game adds interesting decision points with clever card play and choosing the optimal route through the ever rotating flowers.

The player who first gets his or hers swarm safely through the field wins the game!

Evil Corp is a darkly humorous and competitive game for 2-6 players with a focus on Take That, lots of careful Hand Management and some Area Control/Influence. If you play with casual gamer friends they'll get it in one round.

So the game Spiel:

A boardgame of revolutionary technology Ceo's. It's time to save the world, no matter the cost...

Thematically: Internet Tech Titans are the new masters of the universe. The power they wield through technology is staggering.

Now you get to step into their shoes in a game of nasty business dealings, broken promises and compromised ethics.

The game is now commercially available.

Once all the sassy villagers have been eaten and the treasure hoarded up, it's time for some after dinner relaxation. So the dragons play a fun little game rolling around leftover human skulls. Nothing washes down a nice meal of humans like the taste of victory!

Dragoon: Heads Will Roll is a multiplayer dexterity game in which players roll out a fistful of skulls across the table, then attempt to flick themselves around scoring points based on where the skulls have landed. The first player to score 21 points wins!

—description from the publisher

ATK! The Board Game is a 2 player 3v3 MOBA Style Board Game. Assemble your team of 3 Elemental Heroes. Each Hero has a spinnable base that is used for the attack mechanism. Your team is also equipped with 2 towers and a base. These structures have a health system that is easy to keep track of with a counting system built in.

Your goal is to destroy your opponent's base while protecting your own. Any time you defeat enemy Heroes you earn specialty cards that can assist you to victory. These cards include damage boosters for single attacks, respawn delays to assign to your opponent's hero, and much more.

Battling structures is simple, choose your Hero, flip upside down and spin the spinner. Reference your Hero Cards to add a value or action to your spin's outcome. If it's an attack, subtract that amount to the structure's health. Deplete all health on a tower and it is removed from play giving you a clear path to the base. When attacking an enemy Hero, flip both Heroes over and spin. Higher number wins without elemental influence.

Strategically maneuver your way into your opponent's base area and destroy their base. Upon doing so, claim the title of the ATK! Champion. Reset and Play Again!

—description from the designer

For whatever reason, all of the freakishly aggressive predators in your care have escaped!  The surrounding wildlife is in danger!  As one of the only park rangers on duty, it’s your job to protect all of the adorable creatures in your reserve.  You are the only thing stopping a predator from an all you can eat baby buffet.
Most games require a high score to win - not this game.  In PreyCare, you reduce your score by matching up cards in the same column.  The lower your score, the less blood you’ll have on your hands.  Be careful though, matching up cards activate special abilities that may not be what you were hoping for!

The game is simple.  You have to match cards in the same column.  Failure to match up the cards means you have screwed up and your baby creature gets mauled.  Most games require you to have the highest score in order to win.  Not this game though.  Each point above zero is blood on your hands.  The player with the lowest score by the end of the game is the “winner”.  Reducing your score is simple: whenever you match two cards in the same column, their numbers cancel each other out and their value becomes zero.  If you don’t match a column up, well we have bad news for you.  You gotta add the numbers together – it’s basically a kill count, you failure.  Add up all columns together, and the player with the least amount of carcasses is as close to a winner as they come – considering the fact that you’re dealing with adorably dead animals.

—description from the publisher

Confabula Rasa is a cooperative word construction and storytelling game for two to six players featuring a deck of non-linear word fragment cards. You play as ghosts possessing a group of kids in a cabin in the woods, trying to figure out how you died by piecing together your fragmented memories.

Play is started by shuffling the 26 double-sided word fragment cards (Fewer cards can be used for a faster game). Each player is dealt one card (they can flip the card to the other side at any time). One card is placed in the middle of the table. Any player may start play. The first player places the card from their hand onto the tableau so that it forms a word using one or more letters from the card already in the tableau. The player may put the card on top of the card already on the table, or slide the card underneath, as long as the card on the table is not shuffled around. When the first player has formed a word, they draw a word fragment card from the pile and point to another player. The player pointed to must start to tell the story of the death of the ghosts from the ghosts’ point of view, incorporating the word that was just made. For example, if the first player formed the word “angst,” the player they pointed to could say: “The last thing I remember is a feeling of angst as I slumped through the halls.”

Any player may go next by adding their card to the growing tableau to make a new word and pointing to a player to continue the story (as long as a player does not make a word twice in a row). Play continues until all the cards in the deck and players' hands are gone. The last person to make a word points to the player who will bring the story to a satisfactory close in which "Everyone dies!"

The inspiration behind the game is "anyone can be a storyteller!"

—description from the designer

"Voter Beware" (SubrogÄtor Cave, in Latin) is a political dice  rolling game about Food Truck politics. Bernie Salad, Hilaire, Gervais Juanson, and  Donny Sausage all wish to become President of the Food Truck Association, the political position which controls all of the menus on local food trucks. In this game, one to four players will take turns rolling four dice and assigning them to each candidate, who in turn will utilize the die assigned them based on its value.

Possible actions include buying influence, buying votes, enhancing your influence with a funding PAC, or delivering a nasty Dirty Trick to an opponent's campaign, lowering their stature with PACs and potentially hurting their ability to compete. At the end of each turn, a Scandal may erupt which damages a candidate's reputation with the voting blocs that they buy votes from.

This is a unique, one to four-player political game that takes between 20-40 minutes  to play, and with simple-to-understand rules but truly difficult decisions each turn, it's perfect for a coffee shop or lunch hour either by yourself or with friends.

—description from the designer

The Awful Orphanage is a mildly devious tabletop game for 2 to 6 players.

Take control of a unique Orphan and navigate the ever changing rooms and corridors of Ms. Prendergast's Home for Wayward Children uncovering loot, avoiding orderlies and escaping from the nefarious Gaunt & Sinister Man!

Players take it in turns searching rooms in the hope of finding one of the hidden magical items with which you will free yourself from the Orphanage and end the reign of terror.

Use items including Pots & Pans, Bricks and Bottles to fight the Orderlies then ruin your friends turn with tricks including Bags of Marbles and Itching Powder all whilst dodging the Orphanage employees! Whatever you do, always look over your shoulder when trying to escape The Awful Orphanage!

—description from the publisher

There can only be one winner.

Stau-Mau Mau is a family game from the 'Haba Reisspeile' collection.

This game is similar to Uno.  You get to a number of different car tokens in different colors.  On the central gameboard you need to put down your tokens and get rid of all of them.  You can put a vehicle after a vehicle of the same color or the same shape.  As you lay out your pieces you create a big traffic jam across the board.  Some cars have no special function others make the next player to skip a turn, give the player an extra turn or makes the next player take more tokens.

The goal of the game is to get rid of all your tokens, when you have one token left, you need to shout something or you need to take a new token from the reserve.

The game is played totally on magnetic surfaces which is nice.  The players get their magnetic tokens on parking lot cards in their hands to keep them secret.  The board is laid out in the tin lid thus making it magnetic itself.  This makes it perfect to play everywhere.

There are 32 car tokens, 3 parking lots and one main board in the box.

A new set for the classic trick-taking game Wizard, now playable by only two players. This deck includes 36 cards and some new rules.

3 cards are set aside at the beginning, and one of them is turned up to establish the current trump. The remaining cards are divided in 3 groups of 11 cards; each player takes one, and the remaining one forms the dummy deck. Three cards are turned face up from the dummy deck.

Players bid on how many tricks they think they will take in the coming hand. Next the first player plays a card from their hand, then a card from the dummy's hand, and then the second player plays a card. The trick goes to the first player who played a Wizard, or by the player who played the highest trump, or to the player who played the highest lead card. Jesters always lose. The dummy player may win a trick, and in fact its role is to help the first player winn or lose a trick as needed.  The player who won the round becomes the first player and starts the next round.

When players run out of cards, they check their bids and score. You score for making your bid exactly, and lose points if you did not make your bid.
This version also has a special card that cancels the trick in which it is played - no one scores that trick.

First player to score 100 points is the winner.

Julia, Paul, and their friends have hidden bones in the garden for seven little naughty dogs to play and find them. Will you be able to remember where they are and recover as many bones as you can?

The goal in Naughty Dogs is to explore the garden and gather the most bones buried in it. But watch out, because sometimes you will find trash buried in the garden a long time ago. Bones score Victory Points... but the trash takes away Victory points!

In turns, each player must Explore or Dig. When you explore, you choose an unoccupied Garden tile and look at its hidden side, making sure no one else can see it. If you want, you can take one of the dogs and place it on the tile so it goes sniffing around that part of the garden.

If you choose to dig, you take a tile with a sniffing dog from the centre of the table and place them in front of you. That tile is now yours and the rest of the players can't place dogs on it,

The game ends when a player has 5 Garden tiles. Then, everyone turns over their tiles and score a victory point for every bone, but takes away a point for every tile with trash. The player with most Victory points is the winner!

Rome is going to hell. Redneck barbarians are raiding the borders, the economy is in freefall, and the sewer workers are on strike...again. To top it all, mercenaries and slaves have delusions of grandeur (they want to be paid, for Jupiter's sake!), while those petty pencil pushers at the Senate indulge in never-ending rhetoric displays. As a wealthy patrician, you're pretty sure it is expected that you lend your help to Rome in this dire time of need, but then again will your "friends" do the same? The Ides of March are around the corner...'

Vae Victis is a semi-competitive game of decline and treachery for 1 to 6 Roman patricians. The phrase "Vae Victis" — Latin for "woe to the vanquished" or "woe to the conquered" — suggests that those defeated in battle are entirely at the mercy of their conquerors and should neither expect nor request leniency. Keep that spirit in mind when playing this game. Players take turns alternatively, and on their turn, they must go through three phases:


     Doom phase: The player rolls the three doom dice, eliminates one of them, then applies the result of the remaining two dice.
     Support phase: The player can take up to two actions in any combination in the action spots LIMITES, AERARIUM, or DOMUS PALATINA, possibly pushing their luck!
     Influence phase: The player can take up to two actions in any combination in the action spots THERMAE, FORUM, or CURIA.


After this, play passes to the next player. Play continues until a winning condition is met. Note that any player can be a traitor to Rome, and they win if a condition is met that results in all players losing the game.

In The Brainiac Game, players spin the SMART Spinner, then compete to answer questions in five subject areas: Science, Math, Arts, Reading, and The World. Each Question Card has six different questions tailored to grades 1 to 6, so that players answer questions corresponding to their grade levels. The first player to fill his or her brain with SMART Tokens wins!

Tour Guide is a solitaire tile laying game. 
As a tour guide you must map out the city, making sure to create all the locations of your tour's itinerary.

There are 4 different scenarios and, depending on the type of tour, you'll need to visit museums and galleries, parks and piazzas, as well as local restaurants.
The more sights your party experiences, the more points you'll score.
And if there's a historic landmark, world famous masterpiece or culinary speciality to take in along the way, then all the better.

If you manage to create all the itinerary locations, then you ‘walk’ your tour route through the city for bonus points.

The game is just 2 pages of tiles/cards and 1 page of rules. You'll also need some small cubes or similar tokens for tracking.

Tour Guide was joint winner of the 2017 Mint Tin Design Contest

From the box:
Watch out for runny eggs!
Spin the spinner, pick an egg, and press it on your head! If you get splashed by an egg, you're out!

Contents:
Plastic egg carton
10 refillable plastic eggs
Spinner (with plastic arrow and base)
Game rules

Game play:
Before the game a number of the soft-plastic eggs are opened, half-filled with water, and re-closed. The number is the number of players minus one. The eggs are then wiped dry and randomly placed in the carton. The spinner has eight sections: two each of "egg", "2 eggs", "egg another", and "pass". A turn consists of spinning the spinner and doing what it says. For "egg" and "2 eggs" the player selects an egg and presses it on their head, one at a time. For "egg another" the same is done TO another player of their choice. For "pass" nothing happens. Play then passes clockwise. If a player has water on their head, they are immediately out of the game and the turn is over (even if it was the first egg of "2 eggs"). The last player left is the winner.

There is a variant involving filling only one egg no matter how many players there are, and whoever gets water on their head is the winner.

Speed game. On a player's turn they flip a card. If the card contains the correct name of the color as text on the card, players have to slap on the card. The quickest will win all the flipped cards. After all cards are played, the player with most cards won is the winner.

When cats arrived in New Zealand in 1640, the Maori Spirits found this animal exceptional.
The secret of his nine lives stoked envy. Cats need to become mighty warriors to preserve it.
Attacking, defending and strengthening your ranks become the only way to win the game.

At your turn you can :

     play a card on a new place (four places max.)
     reinforce a place by playing the same card or a combination to make a total of nine and create a mauw
     attack an other player with a warrior or a spirit


At the end of each turn, players must have four cards or take cards to have four.
The game finishes when a player have three mauw in three columns/places.

—user summary

Every player takes one box with square plates and one roll with rings of the same color. The 1st player places a square plate vertically into any slit of the board. Then the 2nd player places one into any slit he likes and so on. If there is a square with 3 walls the player whose turn it is to play, must shut it by placing the 4th wall. If the square which he has shut, has no number, the next player continues to play. Otherwise the same player has another turn. In shutting one square the respective player puts one of his rings into it. The squares without number count 1, those with a number count as many points as are indicated by the number.

When all squares are shut, the points are counted and the player who has the most, is the winner.

Meet the environmentally friendly game of the year, FOREST!  The first game from Korea to launch at The New York Toy Fair.

How many trees can I grow?
Protect your forest by being the best Forest Ranger.  Watch out for crafty lumberjacks, and keep the animals safe from dangerous hunters.

Players take two fruit cards each, which reveal the kind of tree they are protecting. Fruit cards stay hidden. Then, players take turns to plant trees around the Mountain Board, adding lumberjacks, hunters, calamities, animals, and forest ranger cards. When the drawing pile runs out, players complete one last round. Then all players reveal fruit cards, tally up animal and tree points earned, and move pieces up the mountain on the score track. The furthest up the mountain is the winner.

Passaportas, The Board Game takes players back to the 1950's, a time in which air travel was still stood for exceptional adventures. As a travel agent, players will try to bring their own groups of passengers (1, 2, 3 and 4 travellers) from to their respective departure cities to their destinations.

The game board shows the world map with all departure/arrival cities, the different connections between them with their fuel cost, the chartered airplane with ten available seats, a fuel indicator and a customs area. Each player is randomly dealt a departure and destination card for each of their four traveller groups and also receives a number of customs cards. The plane is placed on a randomly chosen starting location. If this happens to be the departure location for any of the players' passengers, these may immediately board the plane and all is clear for take-off.

A players' turn consists of the following actions:

     First, two six-sided dice are rolled and the result is added to the fuel indicator. After that, the player may move the plane using one or more connections, as far as the fuel reserve will allow. 
     If the plane lands at the destination airport for any of the passengers that are on the plane, these are moved to the customs area. When enough seats are available in the plane, new passengers may board the plane at the current location.
     Players may now play matching customs cards for the current location, thereby sending passengers from the customs area and/or the plane back home. Any passengers that are still in the customs area after this phase have successfully completed the trip and count towards victory.
     If previously unavailable seats have opened up during the customs phase, the remaining passengers departing from the current airport may board the plane now.


Play then passes clockwise and continuous until all passengers from a player have made for to their destinations.

Red Aurora is a single-player game offering the player to relive the dramatic historical events of October 1917 in Petrograd as a member of the Military Revolutionary Committee attempting to overthrow the Russian Provisional Government. The game is played on two maps of Petrograd showing historically precise locations of stationed regiments, officer schools, bridges, important buildings and the Winter Palace itself. The player will take control of soldiers, Baltic Fleet sailors and Red Guards attempting to overcome the government forces consisting of Junkers, cossacks and Shock infantry.

Over the course of the game, the player prepares the coup organizing Red Guards, agitates garrisoned regiments, gathers revolutionary forces to prevent the government from bringing more troops into Petrograd and arresting the player. The revolutionary patrols seize crucial points in Petrograd, like train stations, communication centres and power plants, facing opposition from the government that tries to uphold the control of the city. The conflict escalates with the revolutionary forces encircling the Winter Palace and finally assaulting and seizing it during the dark October night. 
The game includes 58 historical events, played in variable chronology, and with 60 minutes of playtime offers excellent replayability. Will the Provisional Government be able to retain the control of Petrograd or will the shot from Aurora usher in a new era in the history of Russia?

Test your knowledge of America's National Parks with TRIVIAL PURSUIT®: National Parks Travel Edition. Trivia questions from 100 years of National Park history will challenge National Parks travelers, U.S. History buffs, students and families.

Roll the custom die to pick from six categories: Natural Wonders, Battlefields and Historic Sites, Cultural Heritage, Science and Nature, Wildlife and Wildcard. First player to collect 6 cards wins!

Hook the handy travel case to your backpack and play anywhere, around the campfire or even on the hiking trail!

This is a very simple (but not simplistic) and fast point-to-point ... the boggy Netherlands terrain made roads even more important, especially for armor/panzer ... regiment/brigade game about Market Garden. 8 one-day turns.

Rules are all of 3 pages.  Excellent intro to military/naval history boardgames for family and friends (over the holidays, etc.)  Already really popular at the club here in Oslo.

If Fog of War is used, German (hidden until engaged) strength can be Strong/historical, Weak, and Very Weak - Monty's Fantasy - with the games length ... the requirement to open a road/route up to Arnhem ... shortened accordingly.  The probability of each of those German strengths can be indicated by Dutch Resistance warning of panzers coming into the area ... or not.

—description from the designer

In Totem, players reveal each others' strengths and qualities by forming totems, combinations of an animal card (representing a strength) and a quality card. Every player contributes one animal card and one quality card to each other player's totem.

Players can earn more points if the cards that they played were considered to be especially relevant and accurate, either by the active player or by the other players. The favourite animal and quality cards for that round stay in front of the active player and become their totem. The game ends when everyone has a totem.

The player with the most points at the end of the game wins, but everyone else gains something as well: a greater awareness of how others perceive and appreciate them!

Recreate the Greatest Military conflict in history. Germany versus Soviet Union on the "Eastern Front" in World War 2.
Use your battle and tactic cards, to out smart your opponent, win battles during 1941-1945, gain promotion through the ranks and ultimately win the war. Who will be victorious?

Each year 7 battles are fought, whoever wins the most battles wins the year, whoever wins the most years wins the war.
Each battle the players pick one of their 7 battle cards and then players reveal them simultaneously.  Highest points win.
However events, tactic and campaign cards will also affect your score.
The aim of the game is to get into your opponents mind, remember their past tactics and out think them.

The game has simple rules, easy to learn but allows for tactical decisions and be both quick and fun.

—description from the publisher

A trivia game. Up to four players or teams can play. The players advance in a track of 42 spaces (or "kilometers", hence the name of the game) by answering questions about six main themes.

In this version of Maratón in addition it is possible to bet in the answers of the other players, which are getting lost if the answer is wrong and being able to recover moving back the player marker a space in the board.

Shiver Me Timbers is a highly thematic, strategic sandbox game set in the Golden Age of Piracy. The game is heavily Euro-inspired: It uses a tactical card-based combat system and takes lots of strategic planning to use your available actions to optimal effect and become the most notorious pirate of your era.

Each playing will vary as you randomly reveal five of ten vastly different victory conditions: One game, you'll be rescuing your lost family, the next you might have to conquer enemy ships and fortresses or face the hideous Kraken.

At the beginning of the game, each player secretly chooses two of the revealed conditions as their personal goals. After all players have chosen, they set-up the fully modular board, each of them trying to find a constellation that optimally supports their hidden agenda. Then they outfit their modable ship miniatures, select their starting abilities and equipment and set sails to fight, conquer, trade, loot, hunt for treasure and much more.

During play, every achievement is rewarded with victory points. The game continues until all five victory conditions have been met. There's a final scoring in which players collect extra points if they managed to achieve the goals they chose, and highest point total wins.

—description from the designer

Chronicles of Crime is a cooperative game of crime investigation, mixing an app, a board game and a touch of Virtual Reality.

With the same physical components (board, locations, characters and items), players will be able to play plenty of different scenarios and solve as many different crime stories.

Players start the app, choose the scenario they want to play, and follow the story. The goal being to catch the killer of the current case in the shortest time possible.

Using the Scan&Play technology, each component (locations, characters, items, etc.) has a unique QR code, which, depending on the scenario selected, will activate and trigger different clues and stories. That means players will be able to get new stories way after the game is released simply by downloading the app's updates, without any shipping of new physical components involved.

The VR experience only requires a mobile phone. Players simply put the VR glasses (optional buy) onto their mobile device, and put the VR glasses on their nose, holding their mobile device in front of their eyes, to immerse themselves in the game's universe and search for clues in a virtual world.

The game comes with 1 tutorial and 5 scenarios, but more can be downloaded directly inside the app!
Each session last around 1h to 1h30 minutes and many scenarios are connected to each others in order to tell a much bigger story.

—description from the publisher

You are the leader of the ogres group. Aim of this game is queuing your ogres (dice) a distribution stations and get a beautiful stone. Can receive stones of your choice from the player who placed the most dice at the distribution stations.

However, the demons are not very smart, so they will not move as you would expect. A player who successfully directs the ogres and get more stones than other players will win.

Fat Turkey – The mini card game for 2–9 turkeys.

Farmer Jack is busy trying to fatten up his turkeys ready for market. As one of the turkeys your aim is to try and keep your weight down and avoid being selected.

Turkeys select cards from the food pile which will add to their weight. The food pile also includes cards such as Weight Loss, Poop and Feed Me which will enable turkeys to shed weight and distribute their food cards amongst other turkeys.

When Farmer Jack is selected from the food pile, the round ceases and the fattest turkey is selected for market and taken out of the game.

A strategic little card game played in rounds until only one turkey survives.

The Galápagos Islands are known worldwide as "The Enchanted Islands", a paradise of wildlife inhabited by species unique in the world, the same paradise that inspired Charles Darwin in his formulation of the Theory of Evolution — but any environmental change may disturb the delicate balance of the ecosystem that shelters these wonderful animals, putting their lives at risk!

S.O.S. Galápagos is a board game in which players take on the role of ecological activists whose mission is to rescue animals whose lives are threatened by irresponsible human activity. In order to rescue animals at risk, players must make the best possible use of their resources, which are represented by action dice and helper tokens.

The game lasts exactly twelve rounds, each of which is divided into five phases in this order:

Phase A) Threat
Phase B) Throwing the dice
Phase C) Player actions
Phase D) Resolving actions
Phase E) Preparing the next round

During a turn, a player can perform all the actions that their action dice and helper tokens allow. Through the use of both kinds of actions, players attempt to rescue animals at risk and to fight against environmental threats. At the end of the game, whoever has collected the highest number of rescue points will be declared chief rescuer and win.

The future of the Galápagos Islands is in our hands: To work, rescuers!

Barkolana is the official game of the Barcolana, the most populous sailing regatta in the world.
The winner is the first one to arrive, sailing in his boat a course full of unexpected marine trial, which,if passed, will make him gain money (called "bori", from the name of the wind of the city "bora"). At the end of his turn, the player can use the money to buy in the "bottega velica" (a sailor's shop) some items to make his boat stronger, like new sails, gps, bottle of wine to stop other players, and even cannons to shoot them or forbidden fan or engine (he must pay attention to the sea police).
Also, in each turn the wind will change, affecting the speed of the sailing boats.

—description from the publisher

Il gioco è molto semplice: chi arriva per primo alla casella finale del tabellone, vince la Barkolana. L’avanzamento delle pedine è regolato dal lancio di dado e, a seconda della casella in cui si capita, bisognerà eseguire un compito specifico, tenendo conto del vento a favore stabilito all’inizio del turno e valido per tutti i giocatori. Il giocatore che è di mano dovrà prendere un boro (moneta triestina), utile per acquistare gli strafanici (optional di potenziamento della barca) presso la Bottega velica.
L’aspetto divertente è che per raggiungere il traguardo i velisti avranno a disposizione mezzi non sempre regolamentari: il ventilatore, un motore o i cannoni ad esempio; se avrete la sfortuna di incappare nella Guardia Costiera, dovrete pagarne il prezzo subendo le relative penalità.
Inoltre in mare dovrete sapervi destreggiare di fronte a mille difficoltà: saper recitare una filastrocca in apnea ad esempio, scommettere o mantenere il silenzio radio.
Un’ottima occasione per cimentarsi con un gioco dell’oca molto originale ed imparare qualcosa di nuovo sulle regate veliche, da provare!

Nerdando.com

SECTRE is an abstract strategy game for 2-6 players with a goal of scoring points by building shapes from colors on the board. Pattern recognition skills are sharpened as shapes are picked out in an ever-evolving tapestry of color. Plan your moves accordingly to keep your options open. Your next move will always be on the tip of your tongue; can you manage to keep it a secret?

—description from the publisher

Meownarchy is a print to play card game of deduction luck and survival for 2-6 players. Players will assume the role of one of the royal feline noble trying to claim the throne while the king is gone. The identity of the player is unknown from the other player so everyone must be cautious in playing their cards. At the start of the game, each player receive 1 card each. At player's turn, he/she will draw another card from a shared deck then the player may choose to play the card's effect such as switching a card with another player, or forcing another player to discard his card. When a player has no cards left, he/she is eliminated from the round. The round will end when either the deck was exhausted, only one player remain, or when any player discards the king card.

—description from the designer
